displayed_text:
[Question]

Do you support the government provide basic health insurance for everyone?

answer.text_box: Yes, I do think that there should be some form of basic health insurance for everyone. I also think that people who cause harm to themselves by smoking, using drugs, etc should also somehow have to pay more.

displayed_text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of comments:

  • General sentiment: A strong majority support government-provided basic health insurance. A smaller share oppose it outright, and some offer conditional or partial support.
  • Reasons for support:
  • Healthcare seen as a basic human right that shouldn’t depend on income or employment.
  • Current US system is viewed as unaffordable, inequitable, and inefficient, leading to medical debt and delayed care.
  • Universal/basic coverage is believed to improve access to preventive and early treatment, reduce long-term costs, and yield better health outcomes.
  • Economic and societal benefits cited include protecting workers’ productivity, national competitiveness, and public health.
  • Many point to other developed countries (e.g., Canada, UK) as proof of feasibility; some suggest expanding Medicare as a foundation.
  • Desire to reduce the influence of for-profit insurers whose incentives may conflict with patient care.
  • Concerns and reasons for opposition:
  • Fears of higher taxes, government inefficiency, waste, and bureaucracy.
  • Worries about longer wait times and declines in quality or choice.
  • Objections to expanded government role and increased public dependency; preference for private-sector solutions.
  • Concerns about crowding out private insurance and fairness to those who pay more or work.
  • Conditional/qualified views:
  • Support if a public option exists alongside private plans to preserve choice.
  • Ensure timely access and maintain quality; avoid excessive monitoring or red tape.
  • Some want coverage limited to citizens or targeted to those who cannot afford private insurance.
  • Interest in including dental, vision, and mental health; emphasis on preventive care.
  • Support for a basic “floor” of coverage with the ability to buy supplemental insurance.
  • Lived experiences:
  • Several describe difficulty affording premiums, coping with medical debt, losing coverage after job loss, or navigating slow, complex enrollment processes.
  • Personal stories highlight unmet needs in mental health, dental, vision, and care for chronic conditions.

In sum, most commenters favor a government role in guaranteeing basic health coverage on moral, economic, and public health grounds, while skeptics focus on cost, efficiency, and quality. Many propose a hybrid model that ensures a universal baseline with options for private supplementation, clear standards for timely care, and streamlined administration.

Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary B

Overall summary of comments:

  • Overall stance: Strong support for government-provided basic health insurance. Roughly three-quarters express clear, enthusiastic support; under one-fifth offer conditional or limited support; less than 10% oppose.

  • Reasons for support:

  • Healthcare framed as a human right and core government duty tied to public safety, fairness, and well-being.
  • Affordability and access crises: high premiums, medical debt, and gaps for unemployed or low-income people.
  • Economic and societal benefits: healthier workforce, global competitiveness, and even national security.
  • Preference for public-interest motives over for-profit insurers perceived to deny care.
  • International examples (e.g., Canada and other developed nations) seen as proof of concept.

  • Expected benefits include earlier diagnosis (e.g., autoimmune conditions), inclusion of dental, reduced debt, and fewer preventable deaths.

  • Preferred models/features among supporters:

  • Basic universal coverage for all, with some advocating a public option alongside private plans to preserve choice.
  • Some favor automatic or mandatory participation to spread risk and lower costs; others insist it must not be the only option.
  • Emphasis on equal standards of care regardless of income, race, or status; some explicitly want dental included.

  • Desire for timely access and efficiency, ideally faster than perceived wait times in other systems.

  • Conditions and cautions from conditional supporters:

  • Maintain choice and allow private alternatives.
  • Limit the scope to “basic” care; ensure timely service and administrative simplicity.
  • Protect privacy and avoid intrusive monitoring.

  • Ensure taxpayers see clear benefits and value for money.

  • Reasons for opposition:

  • Skepticism about government competence and efficiency, concerns about quality.
  • Preference for private-sector solutions and reduced dependency on government.

  • Belief that “nothing is free,” implying tax and cost concerns.

  • Additional sentiments:

  • Frustration with Medicaid eligibility thresholds and the burden of medical debt.
  • Some call for reallocating national spending priorities (e.g., away from military spending) toward healthcare.
  • Moral urgency: no one should have to choose between basic needs and care or face financial ruin for getting sick.
